title: Sun Life deal makes it the nation's 6th-largest benefits provider
long_text: Sun Life Financial Inc.Â has completedÂ the purchase of the U.S. employee benefits business of Assurant, Inc., a deal that was first announced in Sept. 2015. The acquisitionÂ makes Sun Life Financial U.S. the sixth-largest group benefits business in the U.S. The transaction includes the purchase of a Dental business and provider network, a Group Life and Disability business, products and capabilities in Voluntary Benefits and Vision, and integrated capabilities in benefits communications, deductions reportingÂ and administration.Â  Dan Fishbein, president, Sun Life Financial U.S., called the deal an important milestone because the addition of the benefits business makes the companyÂ poised to offer one of the broadest arrays of employee benefits to U.S. employers of all sizes. With the acquisition, Sun Life Financial's U.S. group business offers an expanded suite of employee benefits in the U.S. and provides insurance protection through more than 60,000 employers in small, medium, and large workplaces nationwide, according to the company statement. The two organizations expect to bring the businesses together under the Sun Life brand over the coming months. In the meantime, it is business as usual for the brokers and customers of both organizations.Â

title: Report: Proposed Anthem, Cigna merger encountering friction
long_text: Disputes up inÂ the highest levels of managementÂ may beÂ causing aÂ delay in the proposed acquisitionÂ of Cigna by Anthem, according the Wall Street Journal. The Journal reports, based onÂ a series of letters reviewed by the newspaper,Â that behind-the-scenes disagreements are frequentÂ as the two entities await regulatory approvalÂ for their massiveÂ deal. According to the Journal, both sides believeÂ the issuesÂ could delay or derail antitrust approvals, which usually require cooperation for a smooth process.Â The deal is still expected to go through, says the Journal, but the clashes are occurring on several fronts. Mergers andÂ acquisitions are rarely easy,Â but a major hurdle here is that both sides haveÂ privately accused theÂ other of violating their July merger agreement and doing a poor job withÂ submissions to regulators. One major issue, the Journal reports, isÂ Anthemâs lawsuit againstÂ Express Scripts HoldingÂ Co., a prescription drugÂ provider.Â The March complaint accuses Express Scripts of overcharging AnthemÂ for drugs and seeks about $15 billion in damages. But Cigna ChairmanÂ Isaiah HarrisÂ Jr.Â stated in an April 9 letter to Anthemâs board that the litigationÂ was a potential negative for regulatory approval and the combined companyâs value, the Journal reported. Anthem disagreed by letter, remindingÂ Cignaâs board that the latter knew aboutÂ the possibility of a lawsuit early in merger talks. The article outlined other disputes, including some spats between Cigna CEO David Cordani and Anthem CEO Joseph Swedish, and several tales of sloppy document submissions by both sides.Â Spokespeople for both companies declined to comment, according to the Journal. Once finished, the deal would create the largest U.S. health insurer by members (more than 54 million)Â and $117 billion in annual revenue.

title: SimplyHired likely acquired by growing HR tech giant, Recruit Holdings
long_text: Tokyo-based Recruit Holdings Co., a fast-growingÂ HR services firm andÂ parent company of Indeed, the online job and recruiting site, is acquiringÂ SimplyHired, a smaller but relatively matureÂ online recruiting site,Â according to Chris Russell, a recruiting technology consultant with RecTech Media. Coming just one day after rumors about anÂ imminent SimplyHired sale (on or about June 26), Russell told SHRM that he learned aboutÂ the new buyer Thursday.Â  While SimplyHired ranksÂ among the top career sites, Russell said itÂ will most likely become backfillÂ for Indeedâs listings,Â adding a few more percentage points to their already large market share when it comes to source of hire. âThe largest job site in the world just got a little bit bigger,â Russell wrote in his blog post. He calledÂ Recruit HoldingsÂ a very active buyer of HR tech, staffing firms and other related entities. Few others in the online recruiting space couldâve afforded to buy SimplyHired. â¦ One wonders if other aggregators could be on RecruitâsÂ radar.â Jeff Dickey-Chasins, a job board and career site consultant at the Job Board Doctor, told SHRM thatÂ Indeed's decisionÂ was a defensive strategy, taking away a potential acquisition for the competition. But he doubts that the deal represents a new cycleÂ aggregator consolidation. Ethan Bloomfield, co-founder of ConversationDriver, a cloud-based service that connects technology vendors to clients, speculates that costs could rise for recruiters and employers, citing the cost of a click on Google which can be as much as $20 or $30 for some key words.â At this point, there has been no official announcement of the career site mega-deal.

title: Willis Towers Watson merger is now official
long_text: It's official. After friction and doubt,Â Willis Towers Watson began operating TuesdayÂ following the successful completion of the merger of Willis Group Holdings and Towers Watson. The new company, which will do business as Willis Towers Watson, has 39,000 employees in more than 120 countries. As previously disclosed, the merger will meanÂ expanded distribution of Towers Watson's health care exchangeÂ and further globalization of Towers Watson's Health and Group Benefits consulting business, among other non-HR areas.Â Also expected, according to the official statement,Â is $100 million to $125 million in annual merger-related cost savings and approximately $75 million in annual tax savings. According to John Haley, CEO of Willis Towers Watson, the new companyÂ is uniquely positionedÂ to see the connections between talent, assets and ideas and how they can lead to strong performance and growth for itsÂ clients.We intend to help our clients manage risk and engage their people in a whole new way, Haley said. We believe we can change our industry by delivering solutions that are driven by data and analytics, and are integrated, innovative and tailored to meet the evolving needs of our clients. The company works with clients in a variety of industries, including Human Capital and Benefits, and serves 80% of the world's 1,000 largest companies along with many mid-market and smaller businesses around the world. While the deal has had its share of criticsÂ and doubters, it's now a reality, providing HR leaders and employers who are Towers Watson clients the chance to gauge how the merger benefits them.

title: How one employer found a better way to manage legal costs
long_text: With today's growing layers of compliance and government regulation, HR leaders are encountering rising legal expenses. One employer, Indianapolis-basedÂ hhgregg, decided it had enough, racking upÂ more than $70,000 a month in employment-related legal expenses. According to an article at Indiana Lawyer, theÂ consumer appliance and electronics retailer went theÂ request for proposal (RFP) route to cut costs and improve service, eventually choosingÂ Ogletree Deakins, the national law firm.Â Charlie Young, CHRO atÂ hhgregg, told Indiana Lawyer that Ogletree DeakinsÂ had everything his company wanted. For the lawÂ firm's part, the hhgregg deal represented a very different strategy for the way law firms typically work and charge fees. It collaborated with hhgregg to createÂ âOD Advantage,â a flat-fee agreement for legal and employment services that the firm launched 15 years ago. Put simply, the new arrangement made it much easier for hhgregg to get itsÂ employment law questions answered, according to the article.Â Ogletree DeakinsÂ providedÂ information for HR managers and employees when they needed it and solutions for both the company and workers that could help both sides avoid litigation.From the start, the program met with success. Questions were resolved in a matter of minutes instead of eight to nine days, employment claims dropped by 60% andÂ litigation fell byÂ 74%. More importantly, Hhgreggâs settlement amount is 27%Â of the national average. Cost-wise, hhgregg is spendingÂ 44%Â less by taking advantage ofÂ Ogletree Deakins' value-based and volume-based pricing. While Ogletree Deakins' program is not new for the firm, theÂ bundling of services may be the future of law, especially in larger legal matters such as those faced by hhgregg, according to Chuck Baldwin, managing director at Ogletree Deakins in Indianapolis, whoÂ worked with hhgregg.

title: Anthem seals $54.2 billion deal for rival Cigna
long_text: The New York Times reports today that a massive healthcare insuranceÂ deal is now final. Health insurer Anthem hasÂ agreed to acquireÂ CignaÂ that values its rival at $54.2 billion, the latest in a consolidation push among the United Statesâ biggest health insurers. The deal comes just weeks after AetnaÂ agreed to acquireÂ Humana, the smallest of the big five insurers, for $37 billion in cash and stock. If both transactions are completed, they will shrink the number of major health insurers in the United States to three, the Times reports. A combined Anthem-Cigna would have estimated revenue of about $115 billion and serve more than 53 million people with medical coverage.Â Under the terms of the deal, Anthem said it would pay $188 a share in cash and stock, representing a 38.4%Â premium to Cignaâs closing price on May 28, before news of Anthemâs interest emerged. According to the Times report, the merger push among health insurers comes as they look to gain greater size to reduce costs and capitalize on growing opportunities in the government and individual markets. Plus, the appetite for deals among insurers was recently whetted by the Supreme CourtâsÂ upholding of the portionÂ of the Affordable Care Act that subsidizes consumers who buy policies through the governmentâs online marketplace. Tucker Sharp, global chief broking officer of Aon Health, says that with rapid consolidation in the health provider space, carriers are feeling pressure to maintain their position in the game. Combining forces enables carriers to create operational efficiencies and greater scale to leverage better deals with health providers.This could ultimately results in lower costs for consumers, as well as improvements in quality of patient care, Sharp adds. But inÂ the short term, there will be a lot of scrutiny from the Department of Justice and state regulators on these proposed deals. Sharp says itÂ will be important for employers to follow these developments closely before determining how this merger may impact their health plans and longer-term health strategies.

title: Expert: Towers Watson and Willis redo deal thanks to unhappy shareholders
long_text: Last week, Towers Watson and Willis announcedÂ an amendment to the original M&A agreement reached this summerÂ between the two firms. Rather than anÂ all-stock, $18 billion merger, Towers Watson shareholders will receive a one-time cash dividend of $10 per share â an increase of $5.13 per share from the original agreement.The revisedÂ agreement values the consulting firm at about $8.9 billion, based on theÂ closing price for Willis the day before the announcement. Towers Watson shareholders, who had filed severalÂ class-action lawsuits against the Arlington, Va.-based firm, likely prompted the amendment,Â according to an article at Employee Benefits Network. Michael Turpin, executive vice president at USI Insurance Services, gaveÂ EBN writer Mike Nesper some of his thoughts on the Towers Watson-Willis deal. For starters,Â Turpin said that it is hisÂ experience that when a stock deal needs toÂ be amended, the shareholders believe that management is letting the asset go at too big aÂ discount. Turpin added that with Towers Watson's private healthcare exchange business, shareholders felt the company would be worth more in the next couple of years due to a potential uptick in demand (based on the impending Cadillac Tax in 2018, for one reason). And what does it mean if the deal passes muster and becomes reality?Â It's clearly a powerful combination, Turpin told EBN. However, the devil is in the details and the promised valueÂ creation that is multiples of the amended offerÂ depends heavily on the execution of this combination.Â As with many mergers, it is alwaysÂ depicted as a marriage of equals â it never is.

title: Towers Watson, Willis Group merger finalized by shareholders
long_text: After delays andÂ substantial shareholder criticism, Towers Watson & Co. and Willis Group Holdings P.L.C. shareholders haveÂ approved their merger in an $18 billion deal, according to Business Insurance. In a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, Towers Watson said its shareholders approved the deal by a roughly 3-1 margin.Â Friday's vote, which Willis and Towers Watson said is expected to close âearly in the new year,â overcame opposition on several shareholder fronts. On Nov. 19, Business Insurance reports that Towers Watson said it wouldÂ raise the one-time cash dividendÂ to $10 per share (from the original $4.87 per share). According to the article, that moveÂ convinced a majority of shareholders to approve the deal, in which the combined company will be renamed Willis Towers Watson P.L.C. once complete. Its shares will trade on the Nasdaq Stock Market. In a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, Towers Watson said its shareholders approved the deal by a roughly 3-1 margin.Â Friday's vote, which Willis and Towers Watson said is expected to close âearly in the new year,â overcame opposition on several shareholder fronts. On Nov. 19, Business Insurance reports that Towers Watson said it wouldÂ raise the one-time cash dividendÂ to $10 per share (from the original $4.87 per share). According to the article, that moveÂ convinced a majority of shareholders to approve the deal, in which the combined company will be renamed Willis Towers Watson P.L.C. once complete. Its shares will trade on the Nasdaq Stock Market. In an earlyÂ annnouncement about the deal, the companies said the combination of Willis andÂ Towers WatsonÂ will merge two highly complementary businessesÂ to create an integrated global advisory, brokingÂ and solutions provider to serve a broad range of clients in existing and new business lines. Towers Watson,Â based in Arlington, Va., was formed in 2010 by the merger of Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby and Watson Wyatt Worldwide, two of the largest HR management consulting firms at the time.Â The company currently provides a variety of professional services, including HRÂ management, risk consulting and compensation advisory services. Towers Watsonâs One Exchange Platform allowsÂ employers toÂ give employees a regional choice of health plans, and is touted by the company as able toÂ save companies an average of $1,400 perÂ employee, according to a July report in theÂ Wall Street Journal. Executives of the companies told the Journal thatÂ Willis had already been buying the system to sell to its own customers, a relationship that eventually spawned merger talks. Even with shareholder approval, there have been criticisms of the deal, but none specifically related to how the deal will affect employers who currently are served by Towers Watson.

title: How wellness consolidation could affect employers
long_text: The wellness industry M&A trendÂ continues to gain ground, mainly because large playersÂ are looking to addÂ solutions to build their global footprint. But even with that trend,Â innovative start-ups offering unique services also have a place in the sector, according to Employee Benefits News. The article cites theÂ Stay Well Health Management and Krames StayWell merger, and Interactive Health acquiringÂ Health Solutions as the start of the trend in 2014. It also mentioned theÂ 2016Â Virgin Pulse consolidationÂ withÂ ShapeUp and the Global Corporate Challenge. Experts quoted by EBNÂ warn thatÂ wellness industry mergers, as with any M&A deal, can be a double-edged sword for theÂ companies merging and employerÂ clients as well. Workplace wellness' growing popularity is not surprising, as employers whoÂ invest in their employeesâ well-being are seeing several upsides including health outcomes andÂ measurable ROI. The EBN article mentions aÂ white paperÂ published in the Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine which found thatÂ 45 publicly traded companies earningÂ top employee health and wellness scorecard results over a six-year period also outperformed the 500 largest U.S. companies listed on the S&P 500 index by 235%. Howard Kraft, aÂ Mercer partner and North American total health management specialty practice leader, told EBNÂ that employers who find their wellness providers entering an M&A deal shouldÂ focus on the integration details of the relevant vendors, using detailed short and long-term change management roadmaps, technology platforms and people and product portfolios. LuAnn Heinen, vice presidentÂ of the National Business Group on Health, saysÂ managing multiple wellness vendors isÂ a major challenge for employers, so if an M&AÂ dealÂ creates more services and they streamlined on a single platform, it can be a benefit. âHowever, it doesnât always work that way in practice,â she told EBN.

title: Wellness acquisition surge could help employers of all sizes
long_text: Virgin Pulse has been on aÂ shopping spree, signaling a growing wave of consolidation in the crowded corporate wellness space, according to Workforce.com In a news releaseÂ fromÂ earlier this year, Virgin Pulse announced it wouldÂ acquireÂ two competitors, Providence, R.I.,-based ShapeUp and Global Corporate Challenge, basedÂ in Melbourne, Australia.Together, the three companies will serve 6,500 customers in 185 countries,Â greatly expanding the reach of Virgin Pulse,Â a wellness and engagement company that is part of Richard Bransonâs Virgin Group.Â Financial details of the deals were notÂ disclosed, reports Workforce, but the move is a major dealÂ in this nascent space, according to industry analysts. Danna Korn, CEO of Sonic Boom Wellness, a corporate wellness program based in Carlsbad, Calif., told Workforce that it could just be the start of such deals, predictingÂ that 2016 âwill be a big yearâ for wellness M&A activity.Â âThis is the first in a huge wave of these kinds of occurrences, and itâs going to continue to happen,â she told Workforce. âCompanies will either get gobbled up or go out of business.â Mike Thompson, president and CEO of the National Business Coalition on Health, told Workforce that attrition is inevitable.Â âThe whole wellness arena is entirely fragmented,â Thompson said. âThere are literally hundreds of players, and itâs not clear that many have distinguished themselves from the pack. Itâs like the wild, Wild West.â LuAnn Heinen, vice president at the National Business Group on Health, told Workforce that theÂ large employer market is increasingly global and needs scalable wellness platforms and solutions that can be adapted beyond the U.S.. Â If there is successful integration of theÂ companies, each of which had its own successful platform, that could benefit large employers. She added that the abundance of wellness startups alsoÂ means a steadyÂ supply ofÂ niche solutions for employers to try out in tricky, emergingÂ areas such asÂ diabetes prevention, nutrition, sleep and resilience.

title: Willis, Towers Watson ready to merge
long_text: Insurance broker and risk management advisory firmÂ Willis Group HoldingsÂ hasÂ agreed to an all-share merger with the professional services firm Towers Watson, creating a company - Willis Towers Watson -Â withÂ an $18 billion market value, according to a jointÂ announcement. If approved, the deal would create a professional services, risk management and insurance brokerage firm with more than $8 billion in annual revenue and about 39,000 employees in more than 120 countries. After the deal closes, James McCannÂ will become chairman,Â John HaleyÂ will be CEOÂ and Dominic CasserleyÂ will be president and deputy CEO, while CasserleyÂ andÂ Gene WickesÂ fromÂ Towers WatsonÂ will oversee the integration team. According to the annnouncement, the combination of Willis andÂ Towers WatsonÂ brings together two highly complementary businesses to create an integrated global advisory, brokingÂ and solutions provider to serve a broad range of clients in existing and new business lines. Towers Watson,Â based in Arlington, Va., was formed in 2010 by the merger of Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby and Watson Wyatt Worldwide, two of the largest HR management consulting firms at the time.Â The company currently provides a variety of professional services, including HRÂ management, risk consulting and compensation advisory services. Towers Watsonâs One Exchange Platform allowsÂ employers toÂ give employees a regional choice of health plans, and is touted by the company as able toÂ save companies an average of $1,400 perÂ employee, according to the Wall Street Journal. Executives of the companies told the Journal thatÂ Willis had already been buying the system to sell to its own customers, a relationship that eventually spawned merger talks. Â

title: Thanks to ACA ruling, healthcare mergers could affect benefits
long_text: TheÂ merger of Willis and Towers WatsonÂ is likely just one of many to come in the next few years, as the Affordable Care Act and other factors continue to change the landscape of the business of health care, industry experts said to Employee Benefits News. Apart from Willis-Towers Watson, other potential mergers include Aetna and Humana (which is a go) and Cigna and Anthem, both potentially hugeÂ deals within the healthcareÂ insurance business. The ACA is âa catalyst for changeÂ for many healthcare insurance providers, said one expert. Mike Sullivan, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at Digital Insurance in Atlanta, told EBNÂ that these large merger and acquisition deals, âwhether among carriers or intermediaries, are not just about creating greater scales of operations, but addressing market segmentation issues that create better prospects for downstream growth.â Jack Kwicien, managing partner of Baltimore-based Daymark Advisors, told EBN that other significant firms, brokers, carriers, consultancies, and TPAâs will proceedÂ down a similar path regardless of the primary product focus of the enterprise. âWe can expect that group health, ancillary group products, voluntary benefits, property & casualty, retirement plan, and a number of individual financial product offerings will not be immune and will likely experience some consolidation over the next 2-4 years, he said. Â

title: Flock, ADP join forces to serve SMB market
long_text: Zenefits, a darling among cloud-basedÂ benefits startups, is feeling some new heat from a competitor.Â Flock, based in San Francisco, has hooked upÂ with ADP, the massive HR software and payroll provider in Roseland, NJ,Â to provide HR andÂ benefits services to specific ADP customers, according to the San Francisco Business Times. The Business Times reports thatÂ Flock'sÂ software platform is now available to ADP small and mid-sized business customers nationwide, to help them simplify the tedious and complex tasks of the HR process while retaining relationships with existing benefits insurance brokers. The agreement comes on the heels of a legal truce of sorts, asÂ ADPÂ recently shut downÂ aÂ defamation lawsuit against Zenefits.Â Zenefits in turn withdrew itsÂ claims against ADP. We're taking business from Zenefits by doing the ADP deal, Flock CEOÂ Raj SinghÂ told the Business Times. For small and medium businesses, the Flock-ADP partnership means that employers from the SMB market now have an additional option if they already use ADP for payroll processing. For its part, Flock's Singh said they already have partnerships with 17 insurance brokerages, ranging in size from roughly $20 million in revenue to $200 million, and is in deep discussions with seven of the top 10 brokerages in the United States, though those deals are not yet final. We're providing [customers with]Â an intuitive platform to alleviate the management complexities,Â Don Weinstein, ADP's senior vice president of product management, said in a statement provided to the Business Times. Flock customers only need to sign into one platform to gain access to HR, payroll and related data. Â

title: KPMG closes the Towers Watson HR Service Delivery deal
long_text: KPMG officiallyÂ completedÂ of its acquisition of the Human Resources Service Delivery (HRSD) practice of Towers Watson, a leading talent and human capital professional services organization. The closing follows theÂ July 9, 2015Â announcement of the transaction. KPMG, together with other member firms of KPMG International, has acquiredÂ Towers Watsonâs HRSD practice resources in the U.S., United Kingdom, China, Hong Kong, Canada, Singapore, and the Philippines. The acquisition marks KPMGâs sixth transaction in the HR transformation space in the past four years. In addition to Towers Watsonâs HRSD practice, the firm has acquiredÂ EquaTerra, Optimum Solutions, The Hackett GroupâsÂ Oracle Enterprise Resource Planning practice, Zanett Consulting SolutionsÂ and the Workday practice of Axia Consulting. Stephen N. Chase, U.S. Management Consulting leader of KPMG's Advisory practice, said the combination of our global HR transformation teams solidifies the firm'sÂ position as a top-tier HR strategy, transformation and Workday HCM (human capital management) partner.Liz DeVito, associate director and lead for HR Consulting Research at Kennedy Consulting Research & Advisory, called the acquisition a coup for KPMG, which she adds has been making strides in the HR transformation consulting space over the last few years. She also saysÂ TW's deep HR function expertise, years of experience providing HR transformation consulting, long-term partnership with Workday, and internal Workday implementation team of cross-functional specialists create a compelling mix of traditional HR consulting and technology-led innovation in this segment of the HR consulting space. As with all M&A deals, time will tell.

title: Korn Ferry looks to build HR presence by acquiring Hay Group
long_text: Korn/Ferry InternationalÂ is set to buy human-resources consultancy Hay Group for about $452 million in cash and stock, the Wall Street Journal reports. The purchase would split the focus of the company evenly between recruiting and human-capital management, with Korn/Ferry offering clients help with organizational design, compensation and leadership development, in addition to hiring, reports the WSJ. The Los Angeles-based firm has built its talent-advisory practice in recent years, acquiring companies like leadership training firm PDI Ninth House in 2013 and executive-education company Pivot Leadership in March, according to the Journal. The Hay Group acquisition is Korn/Ferryâs largest yet; talent management currently represents about 30% of Korn/Ferryâs business. The deal is expected to close by the end of the year. Philadelphia-based Hay Group has 3,100 employees who help clients identify high-potential workers, train leaders, write job descriptions and analyze pay and incentives. The company also has pay and skills data for thousands of companies and millions of executives. Korn/Ferry told the Journal thatÂ it is targeting annual cost synergies of at least $20 million within a year of the dealâs closing, and CEO Gary Burnison says layoffs may be ahead for support staff in functions like finance and information technology. The company also plans to combine some offices to save on real estate costs. Korn/Ferryâs 3,900 employees are in 78 offices in 37 countries, while Hay Groupâs workers are in 88 offices in 50 countries. Burnison told the JournalÂ he aims to double the companyâs revenue from fees, which topped $1 billion in fiscal year 2015, in the next few years. He sees growth potential in marketing directly to consumers, too, whom he bets will pay to sharpen their skills. The Journal also reported thatÂ employers are ramping up their spending on leadership and manager development, according to a survey from CEB Inc. Fee revenue generated by Korn/Ferryâs leadership and talent consulting business increased by $5.6 million in the quarter that ended July 31, as compared with the same period last year.

title: Aetna, Humana merger could impact health benefits
long_text: The health insurerÂ AetnaÂ said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire its smaller rivalÂ HumanaÂ for $37 billion in cash and stock, signaling the start of what may become a flurry of consolidation in the sector, according to aÂ New York Times article. The deal would bring together two of the biggest health insurers in the United States, impacting how HR managers their health plans.The combined company would have estimated operating revenue of $115 billion this year and serve more than 33 million people, reportsÂ the Times.Â  According to the Times, the proposed merger occurs as the nationâs largest for-profit health insurers seek ways to reduce costs and capitalize on growing opportunities in the government and individual markets. The companies say they will be able to operate more efficiently and negotiate more effectively with large health systems, which have also been consolidating. From the HR and benefits perspective, consolidation could negatively impact healthcare costs in terms of bargaining position. But the efficiencies, along with the expected growth of public healthcare exchanges resulting from Affordable Care Act's recent success with the Supreme Court, also could work in employers' favor. The Times, in fact, says aÂ push toward mergers received a continued incentive last week after theÂ Supreme Court upheldÂ the part of the Affordable Care Act that allows individuals to receive subsidies when they buy policies through HealthCare.gov, the online marketplace.

title: MetLife strengthens global employee benefits partnership
long_text: U.S.-based MetLife and AXA, a French insuranceÂ carrier,Â haveÂ announced plans to further strengthen their MAXIS Global Benefits Network (MAXIS) by combining its existing operations under a joint venture company. Through the joint venture, MAXIS GBN will integrate activities including sales, marketing and client servicing to provide a single, seamless client experience, according to a press release.Â  Within the global employee benefits landscape,Â MetLife and AXA's goal is to buildÂ MAXIS GBN as a long-term partner for multinational clients. MAXIS GBN is nowÂ investing in analytics, medical reporting, and health and wellness solutions, tthat go beyond traditional insurance products. MAXIS GBN will be headquartered in LondonÂ and Mauro Dugulin will be CEO of the joint venture company. Dugulin will be advised by a management committee, led by Dan DeKeizer, senior vice president, Global Employee Benefits, MetLife, and Mattieu Rouot, senior vice president and head of International Employee benefits, AXA. âAs multinational companies continue to grow globally, they need benefits providers who can offer comprehensive, integrated benefits solutions, in keeping with the organizationâs global human resource strategy, saidÂ Maria Morris, executive vice president, Global Employee Benefits, MetLife and co-chairÂ MAXIS GBN Board. By strengthening MAXIS GBN we are best positioned to meet the unique needs of customers in more than 110 markets. The deal between MetLife and AXA is a sign that the two companies expect economic globalization to continue to grow. Large multinationals in the U.S. are always looking for ways to use employee benefits to not only meet talent recruiting needs, but also to retain that talent. MetLife is a major carrier in the U.S., but does not offer healthcare coverage. It's partnership with AXA has givenÂ them that coverage overseas, and this latest announcement strengthens that relationship. Â

title: Towers Watson sheds its HR Services Delivery unit
long_text: KPMG has entered into an agreement with Towers Watson, a talent and human capital professional services organization, to acquire the latter's Human Resources Service Delivery (HRSD) practice, the company said in a news release. Through this transaction, KPMG, together with other member firms of KPMG International, will be acquiring Towers Watson's HRSD practice resources inÂ the United States,Â United Kingdom,Â China,Â Hong Kong,Â Canada,Â Singapore, andÂ the Philippines. The acquisition marks KPMG's sixth transaction in the HR transformation space in the past four years. In addition to Towers Watson's HRSD practice, the firm has acquired EquaTerra, Optimum Solutions, The Hackett Group's Oracle Enterprise Resource Planning practice, Zanett Consulting Solutions, and the Workday practice of Axia Consulting.Â  Last week, insurance brokerage firmÂ Willis announced it was merging with Towers Watson, creating an $18 billion market value firm called Willis Towers Watson. With the recent KPMG announcement, it's clear that Towers Watson's HRSD practice wasÂ not part of that deal. TowersÂ Watson'sÂ HRSD practice has supported a substantial number of Workday implementations during the past seven years. The practice was also named a Workday Consultant of the Year in 2009 and 2010, and recently was named to the Winners Circle in the inauguralÂ HfS Blueprint ReportÂ for Workday Services. Towers Watson has built a strong capability in the HR service delivery and Workday deployment area, saidÂ Max Caldwell, managing director of the company's Data, Surveys & Technology line of business. As our focus in this business shifts to growth of Towers Watson's proprietary HR software solutions, we are pleased the HRSD practice will continue to thrive at KPMG. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed. TheÂ consolidation beat goes on. Â

title: Zenefits CEO steps down over broker compliance problems
long_text: Zenefits CEO Parker Conrad resigned Monday over regulatory compliance issues uncovered in late 2015, Bloomberg reported. David Sacks, current COO and a former Microsoft Corp. exec, will take his place. In NovemberÂ 2015, BuzzFeed News reported that the company hadÂ apparently broken insurance laws by allowing unlicensed brokers to sell insurance products. That lead to at least one regulatory inquiry into the workings at Zenefits. Zenefits made its name by offering free HR services in a software-as-a-service format to small and medium sized businesses, though it largely made money by selling health insurance to its customers. In a followup released on Friday, BuzzFeed discovered that over 80% of Zenefits insurance deals in Washington state through at least August 2015 were sold by brokers without licenses.Â  Monday heralded a large leadership shift at the firm. Along with Conrad's departure, the company appointed three new board members, including Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal. In a memo, new CEO Sacks added thatÂ Joshua Stein, the vice president of legal at the company, will oversee the continued review into its licensing processes. Zenefits was already facing shaky ground in November 2015 for struggling to meet its revenue goals. At its height last year, investors valued the company at $4.5B. Between Aug. 1 and Sept. 30 of 2015, valuation dropped to $2.34BÂ â a 48% decrease.

title: Workday, ADP create an alliance for a 2016 deal
long_text: WorkdayÂ and ADP, competitors in many ways, are cozying up when it comes to their HR technology platforms, reportsÂ Fortune. According to Fortune, the move is expected toÂ giveÂ multinational employersÂ an easier time in standardizing their payroll processes acrossÂ more than 100 countries while dodging the pitfalls generated by the patchwork ofÂ local laws within both country and regional locations. More specifically, Clancy reports, the new enhancedÂ partnership will helpÂ Workday customers betterÂ manage ADP payroll information from within Workdayâs HR suite, which to put it simply, keepsÂ employee records and allows emloyers to take advantage of theirÂ HRÂ data. On the flip side, employers who useÂ ADP's payroll technology access and manage relevant data within Workday. ADP CEO and President Carlos RodriguezÂ said in a statement thatÂ ADPâs increased collaboration with Workday tightly aligns market leaders to deliver a seamless global payroll experience. It is an interesting pairing, FortuneÂ reports, because for one thing, when WorkdayÂ entered the U.S. payroll market in 2008, it became a competitor toÂ ADP -- the 800-pound gorilla of the payroll space. The new integrated payroll system will launch inÂ second half of 2016, the timeframe for the Workday's next major iteration, Fortune says.Â Stuart Sackman, corporate vice president of global product and technology for ADP, told Clancy thatÂ ADP has invested heavily in technology during 2015 to ensure its services work smoothly with other HR platforms, much as it is doing with Workday. Bottom line, Workday is motivated toÂ strengthen itsÂ ADP partnership because at least half of its multinational customers use ADP for global payroll services, Barbry McGann, a vice president of product strategy for Workdayâs payroll services team, told Fortune. Workday has more than 1,000 business customers overall, although it doesnât disclose how many of them are multinational, Clancy writes. Â
